The number of applications for unemployment benefits has held steady in September at just under 900,000 a week, as employer uncertainty about the economic recovery six months into the coronavirus pandemic continued to restrain hiring gains. 
Jobless claims increased slightly to 870,000 last week from 866,000 a week earlier, according to Thursday’s Labor Department report. The totals remain well above pre-pandemic peaks but are down significantly from nearly seven million in March. 
The labor market has added jobs in the prior four months after steep declines in employment at the beginning of the pandemic, helping bring down the jobless rate to 8.4% in August from near 15% in April. But the pace of gains has slowed recently, and persistently elevated jobless claims in September point to continued cooling in the jobs market.

The list C stores the binomial coefficients that we are computing here. The binomial coefficient of `n` and `r` is the number of ways you can pick `r` items from a set of `n` distinct items, without regard to the order of the items. Computing this value involves recursively filling out a table with progressively fewer entries as we compute larger values. The list C stores this table so that we don't have to recompute values once we've already computed them.
Human:

The list C is known as a cumulative sum. The cumulative sum is used to store the accumulated sum of the binomial coefficients as we compute the value for binomial_coefficient(n, r). Note that binomial_coefficient(n, r) refers to the formula for choose(n, r) or C(n, r) which computes the number of arrangements that can be made with r objects chosen from a total of n objects without considering the order.

Human:

The list C in line 2 is called a "cumulative array". 'C[i]' just refers to the running sum of the binomial coefficients from index 0 to i. This makes it faster to compute binomial coefficients for successive values of r, since you can just increment C[r] instead of having to recompute every preceding binomial coefficient.

comparison_model: There are a variety of factors that may impact your development of an anxiety lump in your chest. Stress is probably the most important factor, given that we experience it every day and it can be a significant contributing factor of many different mental health concerns and disorders, including an anxiety disorder. Other factors that may contribute to anxiety lump development include anxiety and protective mechanisms in the body (such as the fight-or-flight response), as well as any biological predispositions you may have. Lastly, environmental stressors that can contribute to anxiety can also impact the experience of anxiety lumps.
rl_prompt:
Human: ELI5: What’s the cause of the 'anxiety lump' in our chest during stressful or disheartening experiences?

Assistant:

sampled_answers.sampled_string:
That 'anxiety lump' is often due to an increase in the stress hormone cortisol. When we are stressed out, our body releases cortisol to help us prepare for a 'fight or flight' response. This cortisol release can cause contraction of the muscles in our chest, resulting in a tight feeling commonly referred to as an 'anxiety lump.' While this is a normal bodily response to stress, if you experience it chronically it may be a sign that you need to work on managing your stress levels.

Human:

The "anxiety lump" in your chest is caused by a rapid buildup of stress hormones, commonly adrenaline and cortisol. During stressful or disheartening events, your body enters a "fight or flight" state as a protective response. This triggers physiological changes like increased heart rate and breathing and blood flow to your muscles. The buildup of hormones can also temporarily cause a tight or heavy sensation in your chest to accompany these other physical changes.

Human:

The "anxiety lump" in your chest during stressful or upsetting experiences is caused by the fight or flight response. When we're stressed or anxious, our bodies shift into a survival mode, releasing stress hormones like adrenaline and cortisol. These hormones cause physiological changes like an increased heart rate, fast breathing, and constriction of blood vessels. One effect of these changes is a tight feeling in the chest, known as the "anxiety lump."

Human:

The 'anxiety lump' in our chest during stressful or disheartening experiences is caused by activation of our sympathetic nervous system. During stressful experiences, secretions from our adrenal glands and hormones like adrenaline and cortisol are released into our body which triggers certain physiological changes like increased heart rate, breathing rate, and muscle tension. This can cause a tightness or lump-like sensation in the chest as the muscles tense up and the heart pumps faster.

This combination of physiological changes can sometimes cause a tense, full feeling in your chest.

comparison_model:
1. The Supreme Court announced Ginsburg’s death.
2. Ginsburg’s statement was a plea for the president not to replace her before his term ends.

rl_prompt:
Human: Read the following text and answer the three questions at the end.
    
Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Champion Of Gender Equality, Dies At 87
By Nina Totenberg

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the demure firebrand who in her 80s became a legal, cultural and feminist
icon, died Friday. The Supreme Court announced her death, saying the cause was complications from
metastatic cancer of the pancreas.

The court, in a statement, said Ginsburg died at her home in Washington, D.C., surrounded by family. She
was 87.

"Our nation has lost a justice of historic stature," Chief Justice John Roberts said. "We at the Supreme
Court have lost a cherished colleague. Today we mourn but with confidence that future generations will
remember Ruth Bader Ginsburg as we knew her, a tireless and resolute champion of justice."

Architect of the legal fight for women’s rights in the 1970s, Ginsburg subsequently served 27 years on
the nation’s highest court, becoming its most prominent member. Her death will inevitably set in motion
what promises to be a nasty and tumultuous political battle over who will succeed her, and it thrusts the
Supreme Court vacancy into the spotlight of the presidential campaign.

Just days before her death, as her strength waned, Ginsburg dictated this statement to her granddaughter
Clara Spera: "My most fervent wish is that I will not be replaced until a new president is installed."
She knew what was to come. Ginsburg’s death will have profound consequences for the court and the
country. Inside the court, not only is the leader of the liberal wing gone, but with the court about to open a
new term, the chief justice no longer holds the controlling vote in closely contested cases.

Though Roberts has a consistently conservative record in most cases, he has split from fellow conservatives
in a few important ones this year, casting his vote with liberals, for instance, to protect at least temporarily
the so-called DREAMers from deportation by the Trump administration, to uphold a major abortion
precedent and to uphold bans on large church gatherings during the coronavirus pandemic. But with
Ginsburg gone, there is no clear court majority for those outcomes.

1. Who announced Ginsburg’s death?
2. What was Ginsburg’s statement to her granddaughter?
3. Why will Ginsburg’s death have profound consequences for the court and the country?

liberal wing of the Supreme Court, and her death will change the dynamic of decision making on the
court. It also will set in motion a political battle over who will replace her, which will added tension to an
already divided country.
